title: Virus News
historical_context: This article was written during the early 1990s, a time when computer viruses were becoming increasingly prevalent, and antivirus software was just beginning to emerge as a necessary tool for computer security.
target_audience: Security professionals, hackers, and anyone interested in the history of computer viruses.
short_summary: The article discusses the state of computer viruses in October 1991, highlighting new virus categories, the proliferation of bogus virus scanners, and notable antivirus software. It also mentions the availability of private contact information for antivirus pioneer John McAfee.
summary: The article further touches on the emergence of misleading versions of well-known viruses, such as a bogus Red Cross virus that sabotages programs. Additionally, it mentions Patti Hoffman's VSUM, a comprehensive hyper-text database for virus information, showcasing the shift towards more organized and accessible virus data. The tone is casual yet informative, reflecting the hacker culture of the time, where sharing information—both useful and dubious—was commonplace. Overall, 'Virus News' serves as a historical document that captures the anxieties and developments in the realm of computer viruses during a pivotal moment in cybersecurity history.
